Copper Canyon

Deeper and larger than the Grand Canyon — Mexico's ultimate adventure in the Sierra Madre

Quick Facts About Copper Canyon

Best Time to Visit
October - November / March - April
Average Temperature
Variable (15-30°C)
Known For
El Chepe Train & Vast Canyons
Airport Code
CUU/LMM

About Copper Canyon

Copper Canyon (Barrancas del Cobre) is a system of six interconnected canyons in the Sierra Madre that's actually deeper and larger than the Grand Canyon. The legendary El Chepe train, Tarahumara indigenous culture, and world-class adventure activities make this one of Mexico's most spectacular destinations.

Neighborhoods in Copper Canyon

Explore the unique character of each neighborhood and find the perfect area for your stay.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The main tourist hub in the Sierra Tarahumara with hotels, restaurants, and tour operators. A charming mountain town at 7,500 feet elevation.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Rim-top area with spectacular viewpoints, adventure park, and rustic lodges perched on the canyon edge. More remote than Creel.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Subtropical town at the canyon bottom, accessible by dramatic switchback road. Warmer climate, traditional feel, and starting point for hikes.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Former silver mining town reached by an epic 6-hour drive into the canyon. Lost-in-time atmosphere with tropical climate and colonial ruins.

{{/if}}

Day Trips from Copper Canyon

Explore the surrounding region with these popular excursions.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Drive or take the train to the most spectacular viewpoints. Spend the day at the adventure park with zip-lines and cable car.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Mexico's second-highest waterfall in a beautiful forested setting. Long drive but worth it for the dramatic falls.

  • Copper Canyon

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Epic drive down switchback road to the subtropical canyon bottom. Town of Urique offers totally different climate and culture.

{{/if}}

Practical Information

Frequently Asked Questions About Copper Canyon

How do I get to Copper Canyon?
Fly to Chihuahua (CUU) and take the El Chepe train from there, or fly to Los Mochis (LMM) on the Pacific coast and ride the train up. Most travelers fly to Chihuahua and do the journey westward (train leaves at 6am). The train can be booked at chepe.com.mx.
When is the best time to visit?
October-November offers fall colors and pleasant temperatures. March-April has blooming wildflowers. Avoid summer (June-August) when heavy rains can cause landslides. Winter (December-February) is cold at the rim but pleasant in the lower canyons.
How many days should I spend?
Minimum 3-4 days: overnight in Creel or Divisadero, with day trips. A week allows time to explore multiple canyon levels, visit Tarahumara villages, and do the full train journey. Two weeks enables hiking and reaching remote areas like Batopilas.
Is Copper Canyon safe?
The tourist areas (Creel, Divisadero, train route) are safe and well-traveled. This is a remote region, so don't stray far off established routes without a guide. The Tarahumara people are welcoming but respect their privacy. Basic travel precautions apply.
What should I pack?
Layers are essential—temperatures vary 30-40°F between rim and canyon floor. Bring warm jacket for rim evenings, lighter clothes for lower elevations. Sturdy hiking shoes, sunscreen, hat, and rain gear (September-November). Bring cash—ATMs are scarce.
Is Copper Canyon bigger than the Grand Canyon?
Yes! Copper Canyon is a system of six interconnected canyons that together are larger (25,000+ square miles) and deeper (6,165 feet at deepest point) than Arizona's Grand Canyon. It's often called 'Mexico's Grand Canyon' but many consider it more impressive.
